title: Housebuilding fuels UK construction boom
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Sep 2, 2015, 12:54 BST - UK Markets close in 3 hrs 36 mins Housebuilding fuels UK construction boom By Szu Ping Chan | Telegraph – 55 minutes ago -100.00 
Sector enjoys longest period of sustained growth for seven-and-a-half years 
Britain's construction sector remained on a firm footing in August, as strong housebuilding activity helped to cement the longest period of sustained growth since before the financial crisis. 
New (KOSDAQ: 160550.KQ - news ) orders increased across the sector, as confident companies took on more staff and optimism about future growth remained high, according to the survey by Markit (NasdaqGS: MRKT - news ) . 
Residential construction was the biggest driver of growth, while commercial activity reached its strongest since March. This more than offset slightly weaker gains in civil engineering. 
The Markit/CIPS construction Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) rose to 57.3 in August, from 57.1 in July. This was well above the 50 level that divides growth from contraction, but slightly under economists' estimates of 57.5. 
The construction sector has enjoyed uninterrupted growth since May 2013, representing the longest period of sustained expansion for seven-and-a-half years, according to Markit. 
This has also led to a hiring boom as August marked the 27th consecutive month of jobs growth in the industry, with staff levels rising at a "robust rate". 
"There is an increasingly positive feeling in the sector as firms continue to get a clearer handle on inflationary pressures, a tight labour market and growing demand. That sentiment is reflected in today’s data," said Stefan Friedhoff, managing director for construction at Lloyds Bank Commercial Banking. 
Optimism about future growth also remained high. Markit's survey showed 53pc of businesses expected activity to rise over the next 12 months, compared with just 5pc forecasting a reduction. 
"The fundamentals in the industry are sound and this is fuelling a bullishness about potential output for the remainder of the year," said Mr Friedhoff. 
A separate survey of the manufacturing sector on Tuesday showed activity slowed in August, as steady domestic demand was more than offset by weaker export growth . 
The Markit survey has painted a more bullish picture this year than official figures, which showed construction rose by just 0.2pc in the second quarter.
